column1: Based on Palantir’s reported Q1 2024 and Q1 2025 revenue figures, what are the year-over-year growth rates for total revenue, total revenue excluding strategic commercial contracts, and US revenue; what is the standard deviation across those growth rates; what is the standard deviation of the quarter-over-quarter changes in the Rule of 40 score from Q2 2023 through Q1 2025; and how do these volatility metrics relate to the Rule of 40 score reported for Q1 2025?,"Here are the answers, with all growth‐rates pulled directly from the Q1 2025 slides and the Rule of 40 appendix, and the volatility (standard‐deviation) calculations shown step-by-step.

column2: Total Revenue excl. Strategic Commercial Contracts

column1: ¹ “Total revenue grew 39% Y/Y … to \$884 million” (Q1 Financials slide)
³ Appendix table, “Revenue Excluding Strategic Commercial Contracts” (Q1 2024: \$610,440 thousand)
⁵ “US revenue grew 55% Y/Y … to \$628 million” (Q1 Financials slide)
### a) Standard deviation across these three Y/Y rates
Let the three rates be r₁=39 %, r₂=44 %, r₃=55 %.
> This tells us that the dispersion of Q1 Y/Y revenue growth across total, excl-strategic and US is about ±6.7 pp around its 46 % average.
## 2. Q/Q changes in the Rule of 40 score (Q2 2023 → Q1 2025)
From the Appendix “Reconciliation of Rule of 40”:
So the seven sequential changes are:
### a) Standard deviation of these Q/Q changes
> The Q/Q Rule of 40 improvements have a volatility of about ±3.5 pp around their average +6.4 pp/quarter.
## 3. Relation to the Q1 2025 Rule of 40 score (83 %)
- **Steady upward trend**: the Rule of 40 has climbed from 38 % in Q2 2023 to **83 %** in Q1 2025.
- **Low quarter-to-quarter volatility** (σ≈3.5 pp) around that upward trajectory underscores a consistent improvement in the combined growth + margin metric.

- **Moderate revenue growth dispersion** (σ≈6.7 %) across total, ex-strategic and US Y/Y rates shows that while US revenue is outpacing total, all parts are growing strongly and in a relatively tight band.
• **High Rule of 40 (83 %)** in Q1 2025 (well above the 40 % benchmark)
• Delivered via **consistently accelerating** revenue growth (39–55 % Y/Y) and **rising margins**,
• With **modest quarter-to-quarter step-changes** in Rule of 40 (±3.5 pp σ) and **tight clustering** of revenue growth rates (±6.7 pp σ).
This consistency of execution is what underpins the record Rule of 40 of **83 %** in Q1 2025.
- Total Revenue Y/Y: Q1 Financials slide (“Total revenue grew 39% Y/Y … to \$884 million”)
- Excl. Strategic Commercial: Appendix table “Revenue Excluding Strategic Commercial Contracts”
- US Revenue Y/Y: Q1 Financials slide (“US revenue grew 55% Y/Y … to \$628 million”)
- Rule of 40 history: Appendix slide “Reconciliation of Rule of 40” (Q2 2023–Q1 2025)"

Given Palantir’s total revenue excluding strategic commercial contracts and adjusted operating income for Q1 2024 and Q1 2025, and its US commercial customer counts for the trailing twelve months ended March 31, 2024 and March 31, 2025, by what percentage did operating expense per US commercial customer change year-over-year between Q1 2024 and Q1 2025?,"Below is the step-by-step calculation of operating expense per U.S. commercial customer in Q1 2024 vs. Q1 2025, together with the year-over-year percentage change.
• From the “Revenue Excluding Strategic Commercial Contracts” appendix (slide titled “Revenue Excluding Strategic Commercial Contracts”):
– Q1 2024 revenue excl. strat. comm. contracts = \$610,440 K
– Q1 2025 revenue excl. strat. comm. contracts = \$878,708 K
• From the “Reconciliation of Income from Operations to Adjusted Operating Income” appendix (slide titled “Reconciliation of Income from Operations to Adjusted Operating Income”):
• From the “US Commercial Customer Count” slide:
Operating expense ≈ (Revenue excl. strat. contracts) – (Adjusted operating income)
**3. Compute expense per U.S. commercial customer**
Expense per customer = (Operating expense) ÷ (Number of U.S. commercial customers)
Operating expense per U.S. commercial customer fell from about \$1.47 million in Q1 2024 to \$1.13 million in Q1 2025—a decrease of roughly 23% year-over-year.
– Reconciliation of Income from Operations to Adjusted Operating Income (Appendix)

- Q1 FY 2026: Assumed-liability acquisitions of property, equipment & intangible assets = \$408 million
- Reference: Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements, “Property and Equipment” section (page 14).
3. Intangible-Asset Amortization as a Percentage of Q1 FY 2026 Acquisitions
- Q1 FY 2026 intangible-asset amortization expense = \$159 million
- As a percentage of the \$408 million acquisitions:
- Reference: Note 7 (“Amortizable Intangible Assets and Goodwill”), amortization expense line (page 15)."

By how many dollars did the fair value of NVIDIA’s CoreWeave investment at April 27, 2025 exceed the carrying value reclassification adjustment recorded against non-marketable equity securities in long-term other assets in Q1 FY26?,"The fair‐value of NVIDIA’s CoreWeave investment as of April 27, 2025 was $1,000 million (see Note 5), whereas the carrying‐value reclassification out of non-marketable equity securities in Q1 FY26 totaled $843 million (see Note 6).  Accordingly, the fair value exceeded the reclassification adjustment by

• Market Performance (Note 5): CoreWeave began public trading in Q1 FY26, enabling NVIDIA to reclassify $843 million of its investment from “Other Assets, non-marketable equity securities” into marketable securities.  As of April 27, 2025, that position was marked at $1 billion, reflecting robust post-IPO pricing.

• Comparative Analysis (Note 6): During the three months ended April 27, 2025, NVIDIA recorded net additions of $649 million and $63 million of unrealized gains in its non-marketable portfolio, offset by a $843 million reclassification and $16 million of impairments, leaving a closing balance of $3,240 million.

• Outlook: With CoreWeave now public, NVIDIA’s future fair‐value mark-to-market gains or losses will flow through “Other income (expense), net” each quarter.  Management has noted in its MD&A that, given the volatility in AI-infrastructure equities, these valuations could fluctuate significantly based on trading volumes, broader market sentiment around cloud GPU providers, and the pace of AI-related deployments."

According to Palantir’s Q1 2025 investor presentation, under the false premise that the Rule of 40 score of 83% was derived by adding the adjusted free cash flow margin to the US government revenue quarter-over-quarter growth rate, what were each of those two percentages, what was the quarter-end balance in cash, cash equivalents, and US Treasury securities, how many deals of at least $1 million closed in the quarter, and what was the US Commercial Customer Count for the trailing twelve months ended March 31, 2025?,"Below is the analysis “as if” 83% were computed by adding the adjusted free cash flow margin to the U.S. government revenue Q/Q growth rate (in reality, Palantir’s Rule of 40 uses adjusted operating margin, not free cash flow margin).
• Calculation: Adjusted free cash flow of \$370 million ÷ Total Q1 2025 revenue of \$884 million ≃ 0.42 (42%)
– “Q1 2025 Highlights” slide: “Adjusted free cash flow of \$370 million; 42% margin.”
– Appendix, “Reconciliation of Cash Flow from Operating Activities to Adjusted Free Cash Flow and Adjusted Free Cash Flow Margin.”
• Calculation: (\$373 M – \$257 M) ÷ \$257 M ≃ 0.145 ≃ 15% (Note: the highlight text calls out +9% Q/Q)
– “Q1 2025 Highlights” slide: “U.S. government revenue grew +45% Y/Y and +9% Q/Q to \$373 million.”
3. Quarter-end balance in cash, cash equivalents & U.S. Treasury securities
– “We ended Q1 2025 with \$5.4 B in cash, cash equivalents, and US Treasury securities and no debt.”
4. Number of deals of at least \$1 million closed in Q1 2025
– “During Q1 2025, we closed 139 deals of at least \$1 million.”
5. U.S. Commercial Customer Count (Trailing Twelve Months ended Mar 31, 2025)
– “US Commercial Customer Count” chart (TTM Mar 31 2025 = 432; +65% Y/Y; +13% Q/Q).
– Q1 2025 Highlights (Business Update slides), “Cash from Operations and Adjusted Free Cash Flow,” “US Government Revenue Growth,” “Closed 139 deals,” “US Commercial Customer Count.”
– Appendix reconciliations for adjusted free cash flow margin."

For NVIDIA, between the current period and the comparative prior period, which grew faster on a year-over-year basis: the combined stock-based compensation expense and depreciation and amortization in cash flows from operating activities, or the combined net change in unrealized gains (losses) on available-for-sale securities and total other income (expense), net in the consolidated statements of income, and by how many percentage points did the faster growth rate exceed the slower?,"Below is a side-by-side calculation of the two “buckets” and their year-over-year growth rates:
1.  Condensed Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows (Three Months Ended Apr 27, 2025 vs. Apr 28, 2024) — Cash flows from operating activities (p. 7):
2.  Condensed Consolidated Statements of Income (p. 3) and Comprehensive Income (p. 4) — Three Months Ended Apr 27, 2025 vs. Apr 28, 2024:
• Net change in unrealized gain (loss) on available-for-sale securities (Comprehensive Income, p. 4)
• Total other income (expense), net (Income Statement, p. 3)
• “Income/OCI” bucket (unrealized AFS gain + other income) grew ~69.8% YoY
– Condensed Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows, Three Months Ended Apr 27, 2025 and Apr 28, 2024 (p. 7)
– Condensed Consolidated Statements of Income, Three Months Ended Apr 27, 2025 and Apr 28, 2024 (p. 3)
– Condensed Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income, Three Months Ended Apr 27, 2025 and Apr 28, 2024 (p. 4)"

Despite a claim that Nvidia's net cash provided by operating activities in the first quarter of fiscal year 2026 fell year-over-year, what were the actual year-over-year dollar change and the items cited as driving this shift?,"Here are the facts straight from NVIDIA’s own 10-Q (Form 10-Q, quarter ended April 27, 2025):
– Q1 FY 2026 (three months ended Apr 27, 2025): Net cash provided by operating activities = \$27,414 million
– Q1 FY 2025 (three months ended Apr 28, 2024): Net cash provided by operating activities = \$15,345 million
Condensed Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows, “Net cash provided by operating activities” line, Three Months Ended Apr 27, 2025 vs. Apr 28, 2024 (page 7 of the PDF).
In Management’s Discussion & Analysis (Item 2, “Liquidity and Capital Resources,” page 28), NVIDIA explains:

•  “Cash provided by operating activities increased in the first quarter of fiscal year 2026 compared to the first quarter of fiscal year 2025, **due to higher revenue and timing of cash collections**.”
Form 10-Q, Part I, Item 2 (“Liquidity and Capital Resources”), second paragraph under the three-column table (page 28 of the PDF).

By contrast to any claim that operating cash somehow “fell,” the company’s own Statement of Cash Flows shows a **\$12.1 billion** year-over-year increase, driven entirely by stronger top-line performance and the timing of receipts."

Despite the implication that removing strategic commercial contracts would temper Palantir’s growth in Q1 2025, by how many percentage points did the year-over-year growth rate of total revenue excluding strategic commercial contracts exceed the year-over-year growth rate of overall total revenue?,"Here’s how the two growth rates compare in Q1 2025:
– (Slide “Total revenue grew 39% Y/Y…”; see Financials page)
– (Slide “Total revenue excluding strategic commercial contracts grew 44% Y/Y…”; see Appendix “Revenue Excluding Strategic Commercial Contracts”)
Thus, removing the (small) strategic commercial contracts would not have “tempered” growth at all—on the contrary, ex-strategic revenue grew about 5 points faster than total revenue in Q1 2025."

Between January 26, 2025 and April 27, 2025, what was the standard deviation of the quarter-over-quarter changes in estimated fair value across debt securities by contractual maturity (less than one year, one to five years, and total), what was the unrealized gain on corporate debt securities reported as of January 26, 2025, and what was the percentage increase in Level 1 money market funds fair value over the same period, considering the company's commentary that gross unrealized losses were driven primarily by changes in interest rates?,"Below is a summary of the three items you asked for, with our workings and cross-references to the Form 10-Q schedules and notes:
1) Standard deviation of the quarter-over-quarter changes in estimated fair value
of debt securities by contractual maturity (Apr 27 vs. Jan 26, 2025)
(see Form 10-Q, Note 5 “Cash Equivalents and Marketable Securities,” page 10, and the maturity breakout on page 11):
Maturity bucket       Estimated Fair Value (4/27/25) – (1/26/25)   Change ($ mm)
(If you compute the sample standard deviation, σₛ ≈ 3,707 million.)
2) Unrealized gain on corporate debt securities as of January 26, 2025
(see Form 10-Q, Note 5, page 10, “Corporate debt securities” line):
3) Percentage increase in Level 1 money market funds fair value
(see Form 10-Q, Note 6 “Fair Value of Financial Assets,” page 12):
⇒ Level 1 money market funds rose by ~ 73.4% over the quarter.

All of the above is reported in Part I, Notes 5 & 6 of the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements, and, as noted in each of those notes, “gross unrealized losses are related to fixed income securities, driven primarily by changes in interest rates.”"

After the one-time SAR-related expense hit in Q4 2024, by how many dollars did the acceleration in Palantir’s GAAP operating income—defined as the Q4 2024 to Q1 2025 sequential change minus the Q3 2024 to Q4 2024 sequential change—exceed the analogous acceleration in GAAP net income?,"Below is the step-by-step calculation, with line items taken directly from the GAAP operating income and GAAP net income slides for Q3 2024, Q4 2024 and Q1 2025.
Acceleration in operating income = (+\$165.0 M) − (–\$102.1 M)
Acceleration in net income = (+\$135.0 M) − (–\$64.5 M)
Answer: The GAAP operating-income acceleration (Q4→Q1 vs. Q3→Q4) exceeded the comparable GAAP net-income acceleration by \$67.6 million.
– GAAP Operating Income chart (Q3 2024 = \$113.1 M; Q4 2024 = \$11.0 M; Q1 2025 = \$176.0 M)

Between January 26, 2025 and April 27, 2025, by how many percentage points did NVIDIA’s excess inventory purchase obligations as a percentage of its total accrued and other current liabilities change, and as of April 27, 2025, what percentage of its net long-term carrying amount of debt are its outstanding inventory purchase and long-term supply and capacity obligations?,"1. Change in Excess Inventory Purchase Obligations as a % of Total Accrued & Other Current Liabilities
Source: Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements, Note 8 “Balance Sheet Components,” table “Accrued and Other Current Liabilities”
2. Outstanding Inventory Purchase & Long-Term Supply and Capacity Obligations as a % of Net Long-Term Carrying Amount of Debt
– Note 11 “Commitments and Contingencies,” Purchase Obligations paragraph (“outstanding … obligations totaling $29.8 billion”)
– Note 10 “Debt,” Long-Term Debt table (Net long-term carrying amount = $8,464 million)
Therefore, as of April 27, 2025, outstanding inventory purchase and long-term supply and capacity obligations represent approximately 352% of NVIDIA’s net long-term carrying amount of debt."

For the trailing twelve months ended March 31, 2025, what is the ratio of the standard deviation of quarter-over-quarter growth rates for US commercial customer count compared to total customer count, and what does this ratio imply about the volatility of US commercial expansion relative to management’s reported 65% year-over-year growth?,"**Answer:**
– US Commercial Customer Count, TTM ended
Using the population formula for four quarterly rates:

A ratio of ~1.33× indicates that quarter-to-quarter swings in the US commercial customer count are about one-third more volatile than those for the total customer base—even as management reports a robust +65% Y/Y increase in US commercial customers (Slide “US commercial continues to accelerate in Q1 2025…”). This elevated volatility underscores that commercial expansion, while very strong on an annual basis, exhibits larger periodic fluctuations than the broader customer cohort."

For NVIDIA, for the first quarter of fiscal year 2026 compared to the first quarter of fiscal year 2025, what were the dollar increase in Interest income and the dollar decline in Other income (expense), net, and what was the primary driver identified for the change in Other income (expense), net?,"The Condensed Consolidated Statements of Income show that, for Q1 FY 2026 vs. Q1 FY 2025:
- Interest income rose by $515 million − $359 million = **+$156 million**.
- Other income (expense), net moved from +$75 million to –$180 million  = **–$255 million**.

Management explains that the drop in Other income (expense), net was “primarily driven by unrealized losses in our publicly-held equity securities due to fair-value volatility in our investments, particularly CoreWeave and Arm, Inc.” (Q1 Commentary, pp. 26–27)."

After deploying Palantir Eval-Driven Automation in AIP as showcased in the DevCon 2 overview, by how much did Wendy's QSCC shorten its supply chain problem resolution cycle and how much did Heineken accelerate its solution build time?,"Here’s what our two flagship customers achieved once they hooked Eval-Driven Automation into AIP:
• Prior state: supply-chain break-fixes dragged out for days or even weeks.
• With AIP Eval-Driven Automation: end-to-end resolution in 5 minutes.
→ That’s effectively a 99 %+ reduction in turnaround time, freeing supply-chain teams to focus on exception management rather than firefighting.
• Prior state: building advanced AI-driven delivery and shipping logic took roughly 3 years.
• With AIP Eval-Driven Automation: the same end-to-end solution was built in 3 months.
→ A 12× acceleration in time-to-value, letting them iterate on new capabilities in the time it once took just to spec them out.

Both examples underscore how Eval-Driven Automation tightens feedback loops in the Ontology—dramatically compressing cycle times, improving operational throughput, and letting customer teams redeploy headcount from manual troubleshooting into higher-value process improvements."

Management asserted that Palantir delivered an 85% adjusted gross margin, sub-$450 million of adjusted expenses, and $220 million of net income attributable to common stockholders in Q1 2025; what do the reconciliation tables actually report for those three metrics?,"Below is how each of the three metrics you asked about actually reconcile in the Q1 2025 appendix tables.
Table: **Reconciliation of Gross Profit to Adjusted Gross Profit & Adjusted Gross Margin**

column2: Gross Profit (per Consolidated Statement of Operations)
Add: Stock-Based Compensation (in Cost of Revenue)

column1: • Start with GAAP gross profit of \$710.9 M.
• Add back \$15.0 M of stock-based compensation in cost of revenue.
• Divide the resulting \$725.9 M by Q1 2025 revenue (\$883.9 M) ⇒ 82 %.
- Reference: slide titled “Reconciliation of Gross Profit to Adjusted Gross Profit & Adjusted Gross Margin.”
Table: **Reconciliation of Cost of Revenue and Total Operating Expenses to Adjusted Expenses**

column2: Total Expenses (Cost of Revenue + Operating Expenses)
Less: Employer Payroll Taxes Related to Stock-Based Comp.

column1: • Take GAAP total expenses of \$707.8 M.
• Subtract the \$155.3 M of stock-based compensation expense and \$59.3 M of related employer payroll taxes.
• Result is \$493.1 M of non-GAAP “adjusted expenses.”
- Reference: slide titled “Reconciliation of Cost of Revenue and Total Operating Expenses to Adjusted Expenses.”
## 3. Net Income Attributable to Common Stockholders (GAAP)
Table: **Reconciliation of GAAP Earnings Per Share, Diluted to Adjusted Earnings Per Share, Diluted**

column2: Net Income Attributable to Common Stockholders
(then adjustments for EPS – not shown here)

column1: - The GAAP line “Net income attributable to common stockholders” per the Appendix is \$214.0 M, not \$220 M.
- Reference: slide titled “Reconciliation of GAAP Earnings Per Share, Diluted to Adjusted Earnings Per Share, Diluted.”
- GAAP Net Income Attributable to Common: \$214.0 M (vs. \$220 M)"

Between January 26, 2025 and April 27, 2025, what was the change in Nvidia’s unamortized debt discount and issuance costs expressed as a percentage of the total scheduled long-term debt principal across all maturity buckets?,"Between January 26, 2025 and April 27, 2025 NVIDIA’s gross long-term debt outstanding (face value) across all maturity buckets remained at $8.5 billion.  Over that same period, its unamortized debt discount and issuance costs declined from $37 million to $36 million (see Note 10 – Debt, “Unamortized debt discount and issuance costs”):
• Total scheduled debt principal (face value) at both dates:
Expressed as a fraction of the $8.5 billion face amount:
Change in carrying unamortized discount as a percentage of principal
= 0.424% – 0.435%  ≈ –0.011 percentage points (i.e., a decline of about 1.1 basis points).
• NVIDIA 10-Q, Note 10 “Long-Term Debt” table, line “Unamortized debt discount and issuance costs.”
• Same table, schedule of “Notes Due …” for principal amounts."

Which four factors did NVIDIA cite in Note 4 of its Q1 FY2026 financial statements for its effective tax rate being lower than the 21% U.S. federal statutory rate, what was that effective tax rate, and what estimated long-term annual effective tax rate did Palantir apply to its income tax effect for market-vesting SARs?,"Below is a summary of the requested tax‐rate disclosures, together with a brief nod to related market performance, year-over-year comparisons and forward-looking commentary.
## 1. NVIDIA Q1 FY 2026 Effective Tax Rate (Note 4)
- 14.3% of income before tax for Q1 FY 2026
- (Comparative: 13.9% for Q1 FY 2025; vs. the 21% U.S. federal statutory rate)
**Four primary drivers cited for the rate being below 21%**
3. Income earned in jurisdictions with statutory rates below 21%
- Q1 FY 2026 revenue: \$44.1 billion, up 69% Y/Y and 12% Q/Q
- Data Center: \$39.1 B, +73% Y/Y; Networking up 56% Y/Y
- Gross margin declined to 60.5% (from 78.4% in Q1 FY 2025), driven largely by a \$4.5 B H20 inventory charge

> “Given our current and possible future earnings, we believe that we may release the valuation allowance associated with certain state deferred tax assets in the near term, which would decrease our income tax expense for the period the release is recorded. The timing and amount of the valuation allowance release could vary based on our assessment of all available information.”
## 2. Palantir’s Estimated Long-Term Tax Rate for Market-Vesting SARs
In the reconciliation of GAAP net income to “Net Income When Excluding One-Time SAR-Related Expenses” (Appendix), Palantir applies:
> (Estimated long-term annual effective tax rate used to calculate the income tax effect of market-vesting SARs.)
- Net income, ex-SAR adjustments: \$164.7 M (Q4 2024) → \$214.0 M (Q1 2025)
- Palantir’s “Rule of 40” hit 83% in Q1 2025 vs. 81% in Q4 2024
- US revenue up 55% Y/Y to \$628 M; US commercial up 71% Y/Y to \$255 M
- The 23.0% rate “excludes certain non-cash items (e.g., stock-based compensation) and is used to provide consistency across periods by eliminating one-time or valuation-allowance effects.”
- Palantir Q1 2025 earnings slides (Appendix reconciliation footnote)"

If NVIDIA's Q2 2025 disclosure implied that the weighted average recognition period for RSUs, PSUs and market-based PSUs was shorter than that for ESPP, what are the actual weighted average recognition periods for those awards and which functional area recorded the lowest stock-based compensation expense in the quarter ended April 27 2025?,"**Weighted-Average Recognition Periods**
- RSUs, PSUs and market-based PSUs: 2.3 years

> “As of April 27, 2025, aggregate unearned stock-based compensation expense was $15.3 billion, which is expected to be recognized over a weighted average period of 2.3 years for RSUs, PSUs, and market-based PSUs, and 1.1 years for ESPP.”¹
- The **lowest** stock-based compensation expense was recorded in **Cost of revenue** ($64 million).
Three months ended April 27, 2025 vs. April 28, 2024:
- Gross margin: 60.5 % vs. 78.4 % prior year (impacted by H20 excess inventory charge)
- Operating expenses (incl. stock-based comp) rose 44 % Y/Y, driven by headcount growth and new product development
- **Unearned stock-based comp** of $15.3 billion is expected to be recognized over the periods above (2.3 yrs for RSUs/PSUs; 1.1 yrs for ESPP).

- Management notes continued demand strength in Data Center and expanding Blackwell GPU adoption but cautions that H20 export licensing and inventory re-use could weigh on near-term revenue and margins.
¹ Note 2, “Stock-Based Compensation,” NVIDIA Q2 FY 2025 Form 10-Q, p. 9."

In the first quarter of fiscal year 2026, what was NVIDIA's interest coverage ratio (interest income divided by interest expense) and what percentage of its net interest spread did net unrealized losses on publicly-held equity securities—driven by fair value volatility in investments including CoreWeave and Arm, Inc.—consume?,"**Interest Coverage Ratio**
- For the three months ended April 27, 2025 (first quarter of fiscal 2026), NVIDIA reported:
- Interest coverage ratio = Interest Income ÷ Interest Expense
- Source: Condensed Consolidated Statement of Income, “Interest income” and “Interest expense” line items (see p. 3 of the 10-Q and “Total Other Income (Expense), Net” discussion under Note 5).
**Net Interest Spread and Impact of Net Unrealized Losses**
- Net interest spread = Interest Income – Interest Expense = \$515 M – \$63 M = \$452 million
- Net unrealized losses on publicly-held equity securities (principally CoreWeave and Arm, Inc.) for the period were \$222 million.
- Percentage of net interest spread consumed = \$222 M ÷ \$452 M ≈ **49 %**
- Net unrealized loss amount: Note 5 “Cash Equivalents and Marketable Securities” (table footnote and accompanying text)
- Calculation based on figures in the Condensed Consolidated Statement of Income and Note 5 disclosures."

What is the unweighted arithmetic average of Palantir’s Q1 2025 Rule of 40 score and its year-over-year growth rates in US revenue, US commercial revenue, total revenue, and total revenue excluding strategic commercial contracts?,"Below is the step-by-step calculation of the unweighted arithmetic average of Palantir’s Q1 2025 Rule of 40 score and the four year-over-year growth rates requested.
– Source: Appendix “Reconciliation of Rule of 40” table (Q1 2025 row), or slide “Rule of 40” chart point at 83%.
b. US revenue Y/Y growth (Q1 2025 vs. Q1 2024)
– Source: Q1 2025 Highlights slide (“US revenue grew +55% Y/Y…”) or “US Revenue Growth” bar chart.
c. US commercial revenue Y/Y growth
– Source: Q1 2025 Highlights slide (“US commercial revenue grew +71% Y/Y…”) or “US Commercial Revenue Growth” chart.
– Source: Q1 2025 Highlights slide (“Revenue grew +39% Y/Y…”), or “Total Revenue Growth” chart (634 → 884 → +39%).
e. Total revenue excluding strategic commercial contracts Y/Y growth
– Source: Q1 2025 Highlights slide (“+44% Y/Y … excluding Strategic Commercial Contracts”) or appendix table “Revenue Excluding Strategic Commercial Contracts” (610,440 → 878,708 → +44%).

The simple (unweighted) average of Palantir’s Q1 2025 Rule of 40 score (83%) and its Y/Y growth rates in US revenue (55%), US commercial revenue (71%), total revenue (39%), and total revenue excluding strategic commercial contracts (44%) is 58.4%. All figures can be found in the Q1 2025 Highlights slides (business update and financial appendix) and the appendix reconciliation tables."

- (Alternatively, using the “Results of Operations” percentages on p. 25:
Interest income of 1.2% of revenue over a gross-profit margin of 60.5% ⇒ 1.98% of gross profit, versus 1.4%/78.4% ⇒ 1.79%, for a +0.19 ppt gain.)

What manufacturing lead times has NVIDIA previously experienced, which fiscal quarter saw gross margins negatively impacted by inventory provisions for low-yielding Blackwell material, and in which quarter are sample shipments of Blackwell Ultra expected to commence?,"1. Manufacturing lead times previously experienced

- NVIDIA discloses under Item 1A “Risk Factors” (Form 10-Q, p. 30) that in periods of tight semiconductor supply “we have previously experienced and may continue to experience extended lead times of more than 12 months.”
- Calculation/Measurement method: the “lead time” is measured as the elapsed time between placement of supply orders (e.g., wafers, components) and delivery of finished products.
2. Fiscal quarter with gross‐margin hit from low-yielding Blackwell provisions
- In the same Risk Factors section (Form 10-Q, p. 32), NVIDIA states:
“For example, our gross margins in the second quarter of fiscal year 2025 were negatively impacted by inventory provisions for low-yielding Blackwell material.”
- Financial-statement reference: see the Condensed Consolidated Statements of Income (Item 1, Form 10-Q, pp. 3–4) for the related gross-margin percentages in Q2 FY 2025.
- Under Item 2 “Management’s Discussion and Analysis” (Form 10-Q, p. 22), NVIDIA notes:
“We expect to begin shipping samples and production units of our new Blackwell Ultra platforms in the second quarter of fiscal year 2026.”"

In Q1 2025, by how many percentage points does the year-over-year growth rate of total revenue excluding Strategic Commercial Contracts exceed the year-over-year growth rate of total revenue, and by how many percentage points lower is that excess than the spread between US commercial and US government revenue growth rates?,"Here’s the step-by-step calculation for Q1 2025:
• “Total revenue grew +39% Y/Y and +7% Q/Q to $884 million…” (Q1 Highlights)
2.  Total revenue ex Strategic Commercial Contracts growth, Y/Y
– From the “Total revenue excluding strategic commercial contracts” slide (Financials):
• “+44% Y/Y and +7% Q/Q excluding Strategic Commercial Contracts” (Q1 Highlights)
• “Total revenue excluding strategic commercial contracts grew 44% Y/Y and 7% Q/Q.” (Financials slide)
3.  Excess of ex-SCC growth over total growth
4.  US commercial vs. US government revenue growth, Y/Y
• “US government revenue grew +45% Y/Y…” (both in Q1 Highlights and the respective growth-chart slides)
5.  How much lower is the 5-point excess than the 26-point spread?
• Ex-SCC growth (44% Y/Y) exceeds total growth (39% Y/Y) by 5 ppts.
• The US commercial–government spread is 26 ppts (71% – 45%).
• The 5 ppt excess is 21 ppts lower than that 26 ppt spread.
(1) “Total revenue grew +39% Y/Y…” – Q1 Highlights; “Total Revenue Growth: +39%” – Financials
(2) “Total revenue excluding strategic commercial contracts grew 44% Y/Y…” – Financials; Q1 Highlights
(3) “US commercial revenue grew +71% Y/Y …” and “US government revenue grew +45% Y/Y …” – Q1 Highlights & respective slides"

Under footnote 11 in J.P. Morgan’s midyear report article “IS THIS THE DOWNFALL OF THE U.S. DOLLAR?” what is the difference in percentage points between the net percentage of investors expecting continued dollar depreciation and the year-to-date share of trading days in 2025 with simultaneous declines in U.S. stocks, bonds and the dollar as defined by the market-credibility metric in the “Tracking the market’s perception of the dollar” section?,"Here’s how the two figures break down (see pages 21–22 of the 2025 Mid-Year Outlook):

1. Footnote 11 (page 21) cites the Bank of America Merrill Lynch Fund Manager Survey, which shows a net 61% of investors now expect the U.S. dollar to *continue* depreciating against major currencies.
- Source: “Nearly 70% of investors surveyed think the dollar is ‘overvalued,’ and a **net 61%**, the highest share since 2006, expect it to continue to depreciate.”¹

2. The “Tracking the market’s perception of the dollar” metric (page 22) defines market credibility as the % of trading days on which U.S. stocks, bonds **and** the U.S. dollar all lose value.  Year-to-date through April 30, 2025, that share is **5%**.²
- Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P., data as of April 30, 2025.
² Bloomberg Finance L.P. data, as of April 30, 2025."

In Q1 FY26, following the USG’s April 9, 2025 export licensing requirements that diminished demand for H20 products, what percentage of pre-licensing H20 sales did NVIDIA’s related excess inventory charge represent, and by how many percentage points did that percentage exceed Palantir’s Q1 2025 adjusted operating margin?,"Below is the step-by-step calculation and the supporting references:
1. NVIDIA’s H20 pre-licensing sales and excess-inventory charge (Q1 FY26)

– “Sales of our H20 products were $4.6 billion for the first quarter of fiscal year 2026 prior to the new export-licensing requirements. As a result of these new requirements, we incurred a $4.5 billion charge in the first quarter of fiscal year 2026 associated with H20 excess inventory and purchase obligations…”
• Source: NVIDIA Q1 FY26 Form 10-Q, Item 2 “MD&A – Recent Developments…,” p. 22.
2. Compute the charge as a percentage of pre-licensing sales
– “Q1 2025 adjusted operating income was $391 M, representing a margin of 44%.”
• Source: Palantir Q1 2025 Investor Presentation, “Q1 2025 Highlights” slide.
• NVIDIA’s $4.5 billion excess-inventory charge equals ~97.8 % of the $4.6 billion in pre-licensing H20 sales (10-Q MD&A, p. 22).
• That 97.8 % exceeds Palantir’s Q1 2025 adjusted operating margin (44 %, Q1 2025 slides) by approximately 53.8 percentage points."
